Kennedy. (“Jack Kennedy was a friend of mine,” Mr. Bentsen said. “Senator, you’re no Jack Kennedy.”) Rarely has an exchange been shown so often, providing endless ridicule of Mr. Quayle.

abstract: Almost everything I thought parenting would be back before I had children has turned out to be wrong. I thought all those people were exaggerating when they said you can’t understand what it means to be a parent until you are one. I was wrong about that. I thought I could compartmentalize my life and my work instead having it all tangled and entwined. Wrong again. I thought I would never lose the baby weight. Sort of wrong. I did; it came back. I thought I would never be the kind of parent who let her child cry himself to sleep or play with toy guns or watch PG-13 movies before turning 13. Very wrong.
lead_paragraph: Almost everything I thought parenting would be back before I had children has turned out to be wrong. I thought all those people were exaggerating when they said you can’t understand what it means to be a parent until you are one. I was wrong about that. I thought I could compartmentalize my life and my work instead having it all tangled and entwined. Wrong again. I thought I would never lose the baby weight. Sort of wrong. I did; it came back. I thought I would never be the kind of parent who let her child cry himself to sleep or play with toy guns or watch PG-13 movies before turning 13. Very wrong.

abstract: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed into law on Tuesday a bill that would enable California residents to register to vote online. The law will take effect once the state’s new voter database, VoteCal, is completed in 2010, according to a statement by Secretary of State Debra Bowen. Now, people in California, as in most states, can fill out registration forms online. But those forms must be printed, signed, and delivered to elections officials. With the creation of VoteCal, registrants will enter their driver’s license numbers along with other identifying information, and their signatures will be added as digital images pulled from the California Department of Motor Vehicles database. California will be the third state to allow online registration. Arizona passed a similar measure in 2002, and Washington State began offering online registration in January.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed into law on Tuesday a bill that would enable California residents to register to vote online. Now, people in California, as in most states, can fill out registration forms online. But those forms must be printed, signed, and delivered to elections officials. With the creation of VoteCal, registrants will enter their driver’s license numbers along with other identifying information, and their signatures will be added as digital images pulled from the California Department of Motor Vehicles database. California will be the third state to allow online registration. Arizona passed a similar measure in 2002, and Washington State began offering online registration in January.

abstract: One of the many disconcerting parts of raising a teen, is that our home phone doesn’t ring.
snippet: One of the many disconcerting parts of raising a teen, is that our home phone doesn’t ring.
lead_paragraph: One of the many disconcerting parts of raising a teen, is that our home phone doesn’t ring. When I was that age, I now realize, my parents had a way to gauge who was a part of my life by the phone calls. No they didn’t listen in. (At least I don’t think they did. I’ll have to go ask my mom.) But the phone rang, and they picked up, and Sheila or Chris or Jay had to tolerate a few moments of conversation before my mother handed the receiver over to me. It was attached to the wall, and I sat on the stairs near the kitchen and talked as the rest of the family walked past.

headline.main: Not on Call

abstract: A watchdog group in Washington has asked the I.R.S. to investigate seven churches in which the pastors violated I.R.S. rules by endorsing a presidential candidate from the pulpit.
snippet: A watchdog group in Washington has asked the I.R.S. to investigate seven churches in which the pastors violated I.R.S. rules by endorsing a presidential candidate from the pulpit.
lead_paragraph: Americans United for Separation of Church and State, a watchdog group in Washington, has asked the Internal Revenue Service to investigate seven churches in which the pastors violated I.R.S. rules on Sunday by endorsing a presidential candidate from the pulpit. The pastors were among 33 participating in a campaign organized by the Alliance Defense Fund, a conservative Christian legal group. The fund intends to challenge a longstanding law that prohibits churches and other tax-exempt groups from involvement in partisan politics. It said the other pastors would, in effect, turn themselves in by sending audio copies of their sermons to the I.R.S. Six of the seven pastors endorsed Senator John McCain. The seventh did not make an endorsement, but said Christians could not vote for Senator Barack Obama.

headline.main: Request for I.R.S. Inquiry Into Pastors’ Endorsements
headline.print_headline: Request for I.R.S. Inquiry Into Pastors’ Endorsements

lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Tex.  The last time George W. Bush came here, on Jan. 17, 2001, an estimated 10,000 people clogged the downtown to cheer a hometown hero who was about to be inaugurated as the 43rd president of the United States. abstract: I have an essay in the Times Magazine this weekend (which you can find if you scroll down or click here) about Sarah Palin, though not about her politics. It’s a look at the explosion of conversation about family – hers and, by extension, all of ours – that followed her nomination. My conclusion is that in talking about Palin we were mostly talking about ourselves, but one facet I did not have room to explore in that piece is the question of why we need this excuse for self-analysis disguised as political commentary.
lead_paragraph: I have an essay in the Times Magazine this weekend (which you can find if you scroll down or click here) about Sarah Palin, though not about her politics. Then there are those who address any elderly person as “dear.”

They see religious services the way that I did when I was their age – as a boring obligation to be ducked as soon as the grown-ups aren’t looking. And yet, as an adult, I find myself repeating what I chafed against, and dragging them along with me because it is “part of being a family.”

Kuntz, the farm boy everybody called Scoop because he always seemed to have a camera slung around his neck, walked around his hometown snapping pictures of everyday life. He did not have the money to have the shots printed, and eventually, as he went off to college and later settled in Minneapolis, he forgot he even had them. Some 60 years later, as he lay dying of cancer, he remembered.

lead_paragraph: The State of Michigan has been granted temporary custody of four children from suburban Detroit after one of them was abandoned in Nebraska under that state’s safe-haven law. A referee from juvenile court scolded the children’s mother, Teri Martin, for leaving her 13-year-old adopted son at an Omaha hospital earlier this week. The referee told Ms. Martin that she had never sought help for her son’s purported bad behavior. Ms. Martin and her husband have three other children, ages 10, 5 and 3. The teenager is expected to return to Michigan by Monday. The remaining children will immediately be placed into foster care.

abstract: An elderly man was killed and four other people were injured by a bomb he was suspected of setting off at a law office in Dalton.
snippet: An elderly man was killed and four other people were injured by a bomb he was suspected of setting off at a law office in Dalton.
lead_paragraph: An elderly man was killed and four other people were injured by a bomb he was suspected of setting off at a law office in Dalton. The explosion set ablaze the three-story house that served as the offices of McCamy, Phillips, Tuggle & Fordham. Jason Parker, the Dalton police chief, identified the dead man as Lloyd S. Cantrell, 77. Robert Smalley, a partner in the firm who was not at the offices at the time of the bombing, said Mr. Cantrell might have been involved in a property dispute case against the firm. “It is my understanding that he was an adverse party in a case being handled by our firm,” Mr. Smalley said. “Litigation is always that is something that creates high emotions on both sides, but we hadn’t had any reason to possibly think it could occur here.” Two of the four people injured were treated at a hospital and released. Two others remained hospitalized, one in a burn unit. Dalton is about 30 minutes from Chattanooga, Tenn.

headline.main: Georgia: Fatal Blast at Law Office
headline.print_headline: Georgia: Fatal Blast at Law Office

abstract: A month after announcing an effort to unseat him, the state’s correctional officers union recalled its recall effort.
snippet: A month after announcing an effort to unseat him, the state’s correctional officers union recalled its recall effort.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, it seems, is not going anywhere. A month after announcing an effort to unseat him, the state’s correctional officers union recalled its recall effort, saying its money would be better spent on defeating several ballot measures. The recall effort suffered a hiccup earlier this month when the California secretary of state rejected the union’s proposed petitions because they neglected to include a written rebuttal from the governor. More than one million signatures are necessary to force a recall election, something the union says would have cost upwards of $3 million. Nichol Gomez-Pryde, a union spokeswoman, said the union would instead concentrate on defeating state ballot measures that involve redistricting and reducing prison terms for drug offenders. A spokeswoman for the governor, Julie Soderlund, said the threat of recall had been “totally unproductive” and an effort by the union to get more money out of the state, something the union denied.

headline.main: California: End to a Recall Effort
headline.print_headline: California: End to a Recall Effort

abstract: The widow of a soldier wrongly convicted in a court-martial 64 years ago in Seattle will receive $27,580 in back pay that her husband was denied while serving time in an Army prison after the conviction, according to the office of Senator Bill Nelson of Florida. Samuel Snow was among 28 African-American soldiers wrongly convicted in 1944 after a riot at Fort Lawton coincided with the death of an Italian prisoner of war. Mr. Snow, who moved to Florida after World War II, died in July, just hours after the Army formally apologized to him and the other soldiers and their families. Margaret Snow, Mr. Snow’s widow, will receive what Mr. Nelson’s office said was $725 in back pay that Mr. Snow was denied, compounded at a 6 percent annual interest rate for more than 60 years. Only one of the 27 other soldiers is known to be alive, and only a handful of the soldier’s families have requested the formal review necessary to receive reimbursement.
lead_paragraph: The widow of a soldier wrongly convicted in a court-martial 64 years ago in Seattle will receive $27,580 in back pay that her husband was denied while serving time in an Army prison after the conviction, according to the office of Senator Bill Nelson of Florida. abstract: The Fish and Wildlife Service is proposing a wolf management plan that could end federal protections for the animals in Montana and Idaho while leaving them in place in Wyoming.
snippet: The Fish and Wildlife Service is proposing a wolf management plan that could end federal protections for the animals in Montana and Idaho while leaving them in place in Wyoming.
lead_paragraph: The Fish and Wildlife Service is proposing a wolf management plan that could end federal protections for the animals in Montana and Idaho while leaving them in place in Wyoming. The agency’s push comes after a federal judge in Montana earlier this month signed an order reinstating federal protections for the wolves in all three states. The judge criticized Wyoming’s wolf management plan, which calls for classifying the animals as predators that could be shot on sight in most of the state. Environmental groups are accusing the Fish and Wildlife Service of rushing to resolve the wolf issue before the end of the Bush administration.

abstract: A national voter group filed a lawsuit against Secretary of State Mike Coffman alleging that as many as 30,000 voters had been purged from the rolls in Colorado.
snippet: A national voter group filed a lawsuit against Secretary of State Mike Coffman alleging that as many as 30,000 voters had been purged from the rolls in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: A national voter group filed a lawsuit against Secretary of State Mike Coffman alleging that as many as 30,000 voters had been purged from the rolls in Colorado. According to the Advancement Project, which filed the lawsuit in Federal District Court in Denver, Mr. Coffman, a Republican, illegally disqualified thousands of voters by removing them from voter rolls within 90 days of Election Day, which is prohibited by federal law. The lawsuit also alleges that a few thousand new voters were improperly disqualified because election officials did not follow federal guidelines in seeking to verify their home addresses. Instead, the new voters’ registration was canceled if a notice sent by election officials to their address was returned within 20 days, the Advancement Project says. The lawsuit seeks to reinstate those voters who have been illegally purged from the rolls. Richard Coolidge, a spokesman for the secretary of state’s office, would not comment on the lawsuit.

headline.main: Colorado Faces Suit on Voter Purges
headline.print_headline: Colorado Faces Suit on Voter Purges

abstract: State regulators blame the pilot of a container ship for causing an oil spill in San Francisco Bay when the vessel rammed a bridge tower.
snippet: State regulators blame the pilot of a container ship for causing an oil spill in San Francisco Bay when the vessel rammed a bridge tower.
lead_paragraph: State regulators blame the pilot of a container ship for causing an oil spill in San Francisco Bay when the vessel rammed a bridge tower. The state’s Pilot Commission approved a report that said Capt. John Cota committed several errors, including leaving port in thick fog on the morning of Nov. 7 and sailing the ship too fast. The ship, the Cosco Busan, crashed into a support tower of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and leaked more than 50,000 gallons of oil. The spill killed thousands of birds and fouled 26 miles of shoreline. Despite the findings, the commission has no authority over Captain Cota because he has already surrendered his pilot license and retired.

lead_paragraph: Carla Moquin is the founder of the Parenting in the Workplace Institute, based in Framingham, Mass., which helps companies design programs that allow workers to bring new babies to the office regularly. I mentioned her earlier today, when writing about ways to reduce the cost of child care, and what follows is an interview with Carla about the nuts and bolts of such an approach. My questions are in bold.

headline.main: Bringing Baby to Work

lead_paragraph: SHIPPENSBURG, Pa.  Supporters of Senators Barack Obama and Joseph R. Biden Jr. often look like Benetton-colored billboards, decked out for their candidates in Obama-Biden hats, T-shirts and buttons. Supporters of Senator John McCain and Gov. Sarah Palin like logo merchandise, too, but tend more toward pompoms (yes, pompoms), homemade signs (“Pitbulls 4 Freedom”), flag pins and chest paint.

abstract: In the face of job losses, belt tightening and economic uncertainty, parents are looking for ways to reduce what they spend on the people who watch their children.
snippet: In the face of job losses, belt tightening and economic uncertainty, parents are looking for ways to reduce what they spend on the people who watch their children.
lead_paragraph: After the mortgage, child care is the biggest expense in most family budgets. And in the face of job losses, belt tightening and economic uncertainty, parents are looking for ways to reduce what they spend on the people who watch their children. It is a painful cut, because there is a person we know and trust on the other end of the decision  one who needs what we pay her (women still overwhelmingly outnumber men in these jobs) to support her own family. And because we hesitate to use the word “cheap” when talking about who is with our kids when we’re at work.

headline.main: Cutting the Cost of Child Care

abstract: Many of the foreigners were in this country legally, and the vast majority were not charged, a new report said.
snippet: Many of the foreigners were in this country legally, and the vast majority were not charged, a new report said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  An operation in 2004 meant to disrupt potential terrorist plots before and after that year’s presidential election focused on more than 2,000 immigrants from predominantly Muslim countries, but most were found to have done nothing wrong, according to newly disclosed government data.

headline.main: Inquiry Targeted 2,000 Foreign Muslims in 2004
headline.print_headline: Thousands From Muslim Nations Were Investigated Before ’04 Election, Data Show

abstract: The documents are central to the prisoner’s claim that he falsely confessed to the bomb plot only after being tortured in Morocco at the direction of the United States.
snippet: The documents are central to the prisoner’s claim that he falsely confessed to the bomb plot only after being tortured in Morocco at the direction of the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Saying he questioned the government’s claim that a Guantánamo Bay detainee had planned a radioactive-bomb attack in the United States, a federal district judge ordered the Justice Department on Thursday to give the detainee’s lawyers documents on his treatment.

headline.main: Questioning ‘Dirty Bomb’ Plot, Judge Orders U.S. to Yield Papers on Detainee
headline.print_headline: Questioning ‘Dirty Bomb’ Plot, Judge Orders U.S. to Yield Papers on Detainee

abstract: A Republican personal finance lawyer from the eastern part of the state reports from a key battleground.

lead_paragraph: We’ve asked our virtual roundtable of voters to send us dispatches about the state of the race from their parts of the country. Some have already voted, but that doesn’t mean they’ve escaped the onslaught of TV commercials, phone calls or mailings. And many reside in states where congressional and state races also have captured their attention.

headline.main: Open Caucus: A Postcard From Ohio

abstract: Just three days before the election, the Republican nominee will be a guest on the comedy show whose ratings have gone through the roof with spoofs of his running mate.
snippet: Just three days before the election, the Republican nominee will be a guest on the comedy show whose ratings have gone through the roof with spoofs of his running mate.
lead_paragraph: HANOVERTON, Ohio — Senator John McCain will appear on “Saturday Night Live’’ this weekend, his campaign said this morning, indicating that the Republican nominee was willing to accept the inherent risks in a comedy spot only three days before the election.

headline.main: McCain to Appear on ‘SNL’

abstract: The Republican vice-presidential nominee’s schedule is a nonstop rush through battleground states.
snippet: The Republican vice-presidential nominee’s schedule is a nonstop rush through battleground states.
lead_paragraph: LATROBE, Pa. – Gov. Sarah Palin is a woman in a hurry.

headline.main: Palin Pushes On Through Pennsylvania

abstract: Days from the election, liberal Democrats are not inclined to relax, given the circumstances of the last two defeats.

abstract: In an interview on National Public Radio on Thursday, Lawrence Eagleburger, who served under President George H.W. Bush, was asked if Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska is prepared to be president.
snippet: In an interview on National Public Radio on Thursday, Lawrence Eagleburger, who served under President George H.W. Bush, was asked if Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska is prepared to be president.
lead_paragraph: BREEZEWOOD, Pa. — Has the list of former secretaries of state supporting the Republican ticket been whittled down to four?

headline.main: Eagleburger Says Palin Isn’t Ready Yet

abstract: The grandest representation of Europe’s obsession with Barack Obama to date is a colossal portrait of his face being made in Barcelona, using hundreds of tons of gravel and sand.
lead_paragraph: The grandest representation of Europe’s obsession with Barack Obama to date is a colossal portrait of his face being made in Barcelona, using hundreds of tons of gravel and sand.

headline.main: Obama Spotted on Beach in Barcelona?

abstract: John McCain would cut taxes generally on par with Barack Obama for those making $100,000 to $250,000 a year, independent analyses show.
snippet: John McCain would cut taxes generally on par with Barack Obama for those making $100,000 to $250,000 a year, independent analyses show.
lead_paragraph: Independent analyses of the presidential candidates’ tax proposals show that those who make less than $250,000 a year would not see their taxes raised under Senator Barack Obama’s plans. Further, Mr. Obama would generally cut taxes more than Senator John McCain would for households with incomes less than $100,000 a year.

headline.main: For Incomes Below $100,000, a Better Tax Break in Obama’s Plan
headline.print_headline: For Incomes Below $100,000, a Better Tax Break in Obama’s Plan

abstract: Some are preparing to turn the party back toward its Reaganite roots, while others are stepping up efforts for a radical reinvention.
snippet: Some are preparing to turn the party back toward its Reaganite roots, while others are stepping up efforts for a radical reinvention.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  No one knows better than Senator John McCain that his affiliation with the Republican Party has been more of a liability than an asset in the presidential race, and as it comes to a close, many Republicans are plunging into a fierce debate over how to rehabilitate the image of their party.

headline.main: Win or Lose, Republicans Will Revisit the Party’s Image
headline.print_headline: Win or Lose, Republicans Will Revisit the Party’s Image

abstract: Though a focus on taxes is helping John McCain, Sarah Palin is weighing down the Republican ticket, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
snippet: Though a focus on taxes is helping John McCain, Sarah Palin is weighing down the Republican ticket, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of voters have concluded that Senator John McCain’s running mate, Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, is not qualified to be vice president, weighing down the Republican ticket in the last days of the campaign, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline.main: Growing Doubts on Palin Take a Toll, Poll Finds
headline.print_headline: Growing Doubts on Palin Take a Toll, Poll Finds

abstract: Ken Duberstein, the Republican insider and political confidant of Senator John McCain, says he will vote for Senator Barack Obama.

abstract: The half-hour special proved more popular than the final game of the World Series and even last season’s finale of “American Idol.”

abstract: The Motherlode and NBC’s “Today Show” team up to help mothers who “opted out” get back into the workforce.
snippet: The Motherlode and NBC’s “Today Show” team up to help mothers who “opted out” get back into the workforce.
lead_paragraph: Seema Kalia left the paid workplace when she went on bed rest while pregnant with her second child two years ago. She was the host of a current-affairs TV show on her local PBS affiliate back then, completely certain of the nuts and bolts of her industry, and of how to do her particular job.

headline.main: Opting Back In
